SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Yes, ma, so he had must know, this morning his watch di he was out hunting all day yesterday, and had forgot to wind it up: so this morning look, mama, that's the place. Well, he ca me to him, and bid me see what it was oc by my watch; and as I had never a one—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: He gave you that money?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Yes; he gave it me to buy one.
Twelve guineas, mama!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Look at me and tell me,— may I believe this?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Ye, indeed. But I am in no such great hurry to have a watch, because I can have one at any time.
Take it, mama; take this money, and put it in your own purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: What, my child!—what!—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: I am so sorry, mama, to see you always . mama! I wish I had a of money, and then you should never any more! for all that I had, y, every of it, I should give it all to you, my dear mama, with my whole heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (ing over him.) Would you, my child?—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: What joy I should have, my dear mama, to see you laugh, and be happy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (embracing him.) I am so al∣ready, my love! I would not give up the plea∣sure I feel at this moment, for all the wealth in your Prince's possession.
O, little can you judge of the feelings exci∣ted in the heart of an unhappy mother, by the compassionate tenderness of a darling son!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: (again taking her hand.) But you accept this money, at least? my dear mama! I am sure you won't refuse me that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Yes, my love, I will take it. You may perhaps be imposed upon by others, and therefore I will myself see—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: What, mama! to get me a watch?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: If you continue with the Prince, you will really require one.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: No, no, I shall not. The Prince has watches every where, and he told me him∣self I should not want one.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Yet he gave you this money that you might buy one?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: That does not signify, for he said so, afterwards, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: You are deceiving me, my dear? and you should never a e word, not even from love to your moter.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: A falsehood! You don't believe me, then? Well, I only wish the Prince was here himself! If he would but ▪ O! re he is!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV2.STAGE: THE PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, THE PAGE.

SP.SPEAKER: THE PAGE
SP.P: IS it not true, Sir, that you gave me the twelve guineas first of all to buy a watch?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (smiling.) Yes, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: And did not you tell me after∣wards that I should not want one?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: True again!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (turning to his mother.) There, mama, there! do you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Your Highness will, I hope, forgive the simplicity of a child, who is igno∣rant of the respect which—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Forgive it? I am enchanted with it! and I only wish it were universal. It is Nature in its first beauty. Speak freely, my little friend! Your mother, then, would not believe you?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (a little angrily.) No, Sir; she would not believe me first; and then after that, she would not take the money.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: How? she would not take the money! And did you, then, so little value my present, as to wish to part with it? I did not expect to hear this.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Sir?—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Had I thought it, I should not have felt myself inclined to have done much more for you. Be honest, however, and own the truth to me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: (looking at his mother.) Oh, Sir!— if you did but know how poor she is!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (taking his hand.) Good-hearted little fllow! you have rificed, then, the sole object of your own wishes, to give succour to your mother? It would be barbarous to suffer an action, such as that, to deprive you of your watch. Here (holding to him his own) take this! and were it the only one I possessed in the world, I would not but bestow it as the recompence of your tenderness.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (receiving it with joy.) O thank you, thank you, Sir!—But does it go?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Yes, yes, be perfectly satisfied; it goes extremely well.

DIV2.STAGE: (The Page runs up to his mother, to shew her the watchboy.)

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Come, my good boy, put the watch up for the present. But since you so well understood how to employ the little money I just now made you master of, here, (giving him his purse) take also this; you will find in it an hundred guineas to replace the twelve you had at first.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (astonished.) What, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Do you hesitate? Take it, I tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: What! the purse, and all that is in it too? O no! it's too much, (offering to empty it.)

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Certainly too much, were it all designed for yourself: but I only put it into your hands to dispose of it. And who can you think of, that might find it most useful?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Who might find it most useful?
SP.STAGE: (He looks from the Prince to his mother, and then at the Prince again.)
SP.P: Ah! take it, my dear mama!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (approaching the Prince.) Your Highness—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P:
I must entreat you, Madam, t wave all ceremony of thanks. You will fin but very little; and I much fear I shall d a greater evil than this may do you good you must be sensible yourself, that child is too young and too helpless to conue with
me. He is not yet of an age to be of any possible service to others. To speak, therefore, frankly, I hope you will not make any difficulty in again receiving him.—You are silent?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Forgive me, Sir

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What?—Speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Forgive me, I ire you. —I am wrong to blush at a poverty I have not brought upon myself; and which, therefore, without any shame, I might openly and sincere∣ly confess your Highness.

Alas, Sir! I must own myself too poor to educate, or to maintain my child! I have long looked towards the future with an aching eye: and now indeed, I will be wholly a prey to sorrow! O, if I must carry back this last and only object of all my cares, to the sad refuge of my own misery—this child, as yet too young to be sensible of the loss he has suffered— (she endeavours to restrain her tears) in — his father! —Ah, Sir! forgive a mother's weakness!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (in a voice of grief, and taking the Prince's hand.) Sir! mama is crying.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Well,—but if you go and live with her?—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (in a tone of supplication.) You won't send me away, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Shall ot? do you then think will not? Sweet little fellow! I am delighted your confidence in me. Well, Madam, stay.—It will, however, surely be a pity, ld his morals, his innocence—but no, there ma be nothing perhaps to fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (looking at him with earnestness.) His innocence, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: No matter, no matter; you may perhaps imagine I wish to withdraw my consent; but pray make yourself easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (fearfully.) But yet, will your Highness think e too presumptuous should I venture—Ah! Sir! may I not supplicate you would explain yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: All I mean, Madam, is, that for a long time past, I have been exly dis∣satisfied with my Pages. Their society and their example, therefore, may perhaps—but, however, it is nothing beyond a perhaps, and we can but try.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (snatching her with eagerness.) O, no, no!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (with pretend ) No! —Well, just as you please,

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: The innocence of y child, is, of all things, most prci to . Ah! I shudder to nd to what danger him!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: You must —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: I can consider nothing, Sir! I see my child in the mid flaes.—If I can but snatch him from th, what matters it that he be left naked in my arms?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But witt either money or edu∣cation, what is to become of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Whatever it may please God. I resign myself to his decrees! If he is not able to support his birth, let him plough in the fields! O let him, so he preserve but his innocence; let him die in the very bosom of poverty!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (in his natural voice.) This, in∣deed, is thinking nobly: and I see how thorough∣ly you merit all that my situation in life can ena∣ble me to do for you.
In what can I serve you? Tell me, what assistance can I give you? Speak openly; ask what you please; believe me, Madam, you have now a friend before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (with emotion.) Ah, Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Tell me, in the first place, what is your situation at present? What is the condition of your estate?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: It is utterly impossible for to save it.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Your debts, then, are consider∣able , you have law-suits. Have of them?
None, Sir. There is one the succon, which to ha decided in my which my right is icontestible; riches and power! I quit∣ted a compro∣mise; I succeed.

joice that you could not; for you shall nowhere ample justice, without making any to obtain it. I plight my to you that this shll be done. You must also favour me with cepting a pension of a hundred a year. I only wish I could as irt all your other difficulties.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (casting herself at his feet.) Oh! Sir! your Highness is too, too good!—How can I ever—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (raising her.) What are you do∣ing? Rise, rise, Madam. I merely acquit my∣self of what I owe to the memory of the offi∣cer whose widow you are: and I only do for you that which I wish to do for every one whose virtues so deeply penetrate my heart. Tell me, do you hesitate any longer in taking back your child?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Is it possible, Sir, I can for∣get—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: And you, my litle friend, are you willing to return to your mother?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (holding his watch in his hand.) To go back to mama? O yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: I know, however, that you love me: you would willingly, therefore, stay with me also?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: O very, very willingly, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But, in giving you again to your mother, I must part from you myself: and you have so earnestly entreated me to keep you! —Your mother, too, has thrown you so whol∣ly under my protection!—Well, I must try some other means to conciliate matters. Stay here, Madam, a little while; I shall be with you in a moment. (He goes out.)

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XII.
DIV2.STAGE: Mrs. DERFORD, THE PAGE.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. DERFORD
SP.P: O BLESSED day! O unexpected happi∣ness!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Well, dear mama, well, are you quite happy now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (tenderly drawing him to her.) My child! my dearest child!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: But you don't seem to be glad, my dear mama? Why, you ought to be quite in high spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: My own felicity makes me blush: it reproaches me for the little confidence I have placed in Providence, and for the bitter affliction I have felt that ever I gave you birth. It was but a moment after hearing of the loss of your father, I looked upon you with com∣passion and terror; I wept that I had brought you into the world! (She takes him in her arms, and embraces him.) Yet it was thou that wert destined to comfort and support thy miserable mother! and by thy own little hands were her tears to be dried! O Heaven, what can I now desire? Nothing, nothing, but to be satisfied of your brother's future lot, and then my hap∣piness would be perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: My brother's lot! What do you mean, mama?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Should the Prince know what he has done—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Why, if he did know it, he would take no notice of it. You see, my dear mama, how generous and good he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Yes, my love, to us, who are guilty of no fault.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Besides, mama, he has promised me to keep the secret, and never let the Colonel hear of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (alarmed.) How! has he pro∣mised you that?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: He has indeed. So now you need not be frightened any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: I am quite confounded! You have told him, then—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: O, hardly any thing, mama; only just what I knew. But he asked me him∣self about my brother's behaviour, and so I could not tell stories. You know you always bid me not do that, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: But, my love, my dear child—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Why what, mama! are you un∣easy? are you vexed?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Am I uneasy! good Heaven, am I uneasy! Ah! should the Prince enquire further,—should he learn—thou mayest per∣haps have undone thy mother, and thy brother; thou mayest have plunged us into a gulph of affliction and ruin!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (ready to cry.) A gulph of affliction?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Some one is coming. (She embraces and soothes him) Say nothing: dry up your tears; they will but serve to make the evil yet more serious. Be quiet, be composed!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XIII.
DIV2.STAGE: Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE, The PRINCE, followed by Capt. DETTIN∣GEN, and Ensign DERFORD.

SP.SPEAKER: THE PRINCE.
SP.P: COME in, Gentlemen.
You, then, are young Derford, son to the brave Major!

SP.SPEAKER: The Ensign
SP.P: (bowing very low.) Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: To me that is a great recom∣mendation. Your father was a man of high honour, and an officer of noble courage. Doubt∣less his example has awakened your emulation, and you make it your study to render yourself worthy of being called his son?

SP.SPEAKER: The Ensign.
SP.P: I only do my duty, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: And that is doing every thing. The greatest of men cannot do more. You see here, Sir, your mother. Her virtues, and the fair promise I see in your amiable little brother of inheriting them, have given me the most ad∣vantageous idea of all your family; and it is owing to this that I have desired to assemble you all before me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Ensign
SP.P: (still bowing.) Your Highness does me the utmost honour.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: I do you no more than I con∣clude you deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: The Ensign.
SP.P: Your Highness judges of me most favourably.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: In short, Sir, I only wait for a fuller conviction that the judgement I am incli∣ned to form of you, is right, in order to make your fortune. That easy and assured air, how∣ever, which so well becomes you—

SP.SPEAKER: The Ensign.
SP.P: O Sir —

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P:
Bespeaks — you must permit me to be explicit,—a soul that is either very noble, or utterly corrupt. There is no suspect∣ing the son who is born of such parents; no, it is not possible. Tell me, then, Sir, what is
there I can do for you? One step higher would not much advance you: what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: The Ensign
SP.P: (rubbing his hands.) No, certain∣ly, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But if we should jump over that step?—A Captain's rank, and a company, seem always the grand aim of every young offi∣cer. But first, however, (turning suddenly to Captain Dettingen) what have you to say, Sir, of your nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Dettingen
SP.P: (confused.) Me, Sir! what have I to say of him?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: One would suppose some harm?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Dettingen.
SP.P: No, Sir, on the contrary, much good. I think he has courage, and will make a brave —

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (looking at the Ensign with an air of satisfaction.) Indeed? Is this true?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Dettingen.
SP.P: Besides, he is of an exceed∣ing good height, and figure.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Certainly; he is a very fine young man. But what are his morals? What is his conduct? I am ashamed, indeed, to ques∣tion you upon such trifles: yet I wish to know his character.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Dettingen
SP.P: (smiling.) Why, Sir, per∣haps rather too much gaiety, sometimes—a lit∣tle rash and hasty; but then, as your Highness knows, that does not misbecome a soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: As I know, Sir? Upon my word, this is quite new to me! Nothing more remains, then, Madam, but that you give me your testimony. What do you say yourself for your son?—
Nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: What, Sir, should I say?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What you really think of him; the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Is that, Sir, possible? If he merits my praise, ought I to give it in his pre∣sence? or if he deserves my blame, ought he to receive it before the master of his destiny?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (smiling.) Well parried, Madam! You join to the tenderness of a mother, all the address of a woman. It is impossible not to ad∣mire you. Sir, (turning gravely to the Ensign) every body has some method of his own; I, also, have mine. When I mean to promote any officer, I begin by putting him under arrest. What think you of this way?

SP.SPEAKER: The Ensign
SP.P: (alarmed.) Your Highness—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: 'Tis my custom. Give up your sword to the Captain. Behaviour more modest might have made me pardon all; but this confident air, this forward assurance—with a conscience such as yours!—What can be ho∣ped from a young man so bold and so unmoved, who must be certain he has merited my dis∣pleasure, and who knows how unworthily he has treated the best of mothers: but who, not∣withstanding—Captain Dettingen, see that he is kept under arrest for a month. I ask no ex∣planation of what is past; I am deerred, Madam, by my esteem for you, by the manner in which I gained my information, and yet more, by the circumstances which make me presume that his fault is of a very serious nature.
SP.STAGE: (In a voice of firmness and severity:)
SP.P:
Captain Dettingen, if any thing wrong should happen in future, I insist upon being told of it
instantly. Mark me, Sir, instantly! My inten∣tion is to promote the young man hereafter; and neither you, Captain, nor you, Madam, must attempt any alteration in my plan of pro∣ceeding.
I charge you upon no account to give to him even the smallest trifle by way of present. His pay ought to satisfy him. Let him learn to limit his expences.
SP.STAGE: (He makes a motion to him with his hand to retire.)
SP.P: Go, Sir; and submit to the punishment you have deserved.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XIV.
DIV2.STAGE: The PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE.

SP.SPEAKER: THE PRINCE
SP.P: YOU seem melancholy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford
SP.P: (respectfully.) Alas, Sir, am I not a mother?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But you are not one of those weak mothers, who, to save their children from a little present pain, would not have t errors corrected?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: That, indeed, would be mis∣taken fondness. No, Sir, my sole fear is, less he should have lost for ever the favour of his Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: No, no, take courage, Madam. My view is merely to make him merit the ser∣vices I mean to do him. Youth has much claim to indulgence; and I most willingly, for the present, forgive his errors and follies; but I cannot do it always. The pardon which for once may awaken the love of virtue by repen∣tance, if repeated, may only strengthen a dis∣position to vice. But for the rest, be not under any uneasiness. The young man will be brought into the right path; and my good offices towards him shall keep pace with his reformation.
As to this child, what do you think are my intentions for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: I cannot tell, Sir; but I well know they must be all for his happiness and ad∣vantage. Oh, Sir! the day has never passed, that I have not paid the tribute of veneration to your Highness' virtues; but I am now first sensible how short it has been of your noble desert.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What are you saying? I see you do not know me. My design is but to give a brave officer to the State, and a faithful servant to myself; and to bring up a friend for my son, who shall one day be as willing to sa∣crifice his life to him, as his father was to me.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XV.
DIV2.STAGE: The PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE, An ATTENDANT.

SP.SPEAKER: THE ATTENDANT.
SP.P: PLEASE your Highness, the Master of the Royal Academy.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Bid him come in. I flatter myself, Madam, you will only have to hear my design, in order to approve it.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XVI.
DIV2.STAGE: The PRINCE, Mrs. DERFORD, The PAGE, And the MASTER.

SP.SPEAKER: THE MASTER
SP.P: I ATTEND your Highness' pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Good-morrow to you, Sir; I am glad to see you. Will you please to inform me what is the yearly pay for children of high rank at the Academy?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: Of high rank, Sir? why, ac∣cording to circumstances.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Pray answer to the point.

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: Fifty pounds, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Very well. I mean to put this child under your care. And as I iend to sup∣ply the place of a father to him, I desire that he may have every thing that a man of the first condition would order for his son. But, pray tell me who has the charge of watching over these young people? for that is the most essen∣tial point in their education.

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: The assistant masters, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P:
And, no doubt, they are equal to that employment? However, as I do not know them, it is upon you solely I shall depend. I have the greatest confidence in you. Are you
willing to undertake, yourself, the care of this child's education?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: It is but my duty, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: I do not ask it of you as a duty; I wish to know if you can consent to it with pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: In my duty, Sir, I always find my pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Very well; you may then rely upon my gratitude.
SP.STAGE: (To the Page, taking him by the hand:)
SP.P: Come hither, my little friend. You see this gentleman? He is good and amiable. Will you go and live with him?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (after looking a little while at the master) Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But understand, at the same time, in what light you are to consider him. He will be your master, and your benefactor. He will be intitled to your implicit obedience, and your affectionate respect. And if ever he has any reason to be displeased with you —
O no, Sir! indeed he never shall!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: You have seen that I can be no less severe than indulgent; the least complaint, therefore—

SP.SPEAKER: THE PAGE
SP.P: (To the master, taking hold of his hand.) Indeed, Sir, you shall never have to complain of me! only believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What do you think of the boy?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: It is enough, Sir, that I receive him from the hands of your Highness, to make him as dear to me as my own son.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: He may go with you, then, immediately. You give your consent, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Good Heaven, Sir, my con∣sent!—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Go, then, my boy! Walk ever in the paths of virtue and honour, and make yourself perfectly easy about every thing else; your wants shall all be fully supplied. But why do you look so sad?

SP.SPEAKER: THE PAGE
SP.P: (respectfully kissing his hand) Long live your Highness! and may you be very hap∣py, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (tenderly.) And you too, my young friend, my new son, may you, too, be happy! How grateful his little heart is already! I shall now, Sir, release you. And do you Madam, accompany him, and satisfy yourself of what becomes of your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. DERFORD
SP.P: (throwing herself at his fet.) Can I, Sir, force myself away, without expre¦ing—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What are you about? I do not like this!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: Permit me, Sir, to—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (raising her.) No, no, rise, Ma∣dam; I cannot bear to see any body in that posture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Derford.
SP.P: I must, then, obey your Highness, and retire. (Lifting her hands up to∣wards Heaven.) It is to God that I must pros∣trate myself, to supplicate him long to preserve the life of the most generous of Princes and of men.

SP.SPEAKER: THE PRINCE
SP.P: (graciously following her a few steps.) Adieu, Madam; and all happiness at∣tend you!
